{{notability|Biographies|date=January 2018}} {{orphan|date=January 2018}} {{Infobox person | honorific_prefix = | name = Lisa Winning | honorific_suffix = | image = | image_size = | alt = | caption = | birth_name = | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Sydney, Australia]] | residence = | occupation = | years_active = | networth = | spouse = | children = | parents = | relatives = | alma_mater = [[London School of Economics]] }} '''Lisa Winning''' is an entrepreneur and digital technologist. She was the Founder and CEO of New York and Silicon Valley based startup, HeTexted. The website and app for crowdsourced advice led to book deals <ref>{{cite news|title='He Texted' Blog Scores Book Deal (Exclusive)|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/hetextedcom-blog-book-deal-395346|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=The Hollywood Reporter|date=November 28, 2012}}</ref> with Penguin Random House <ref>{{cite book|last1=Winning|first1=Lisa|title=HeTexted the ultimate guide to decoding guys|date=April 2014|publisher=Penguin Random House|location=United Kingdom and Commonwealth|isbn=9781448184705|url=https://www.penguin.co.uk/authors/lisa-winning/1072737/|accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref>, and Simon & Schuster, <ref>{{cite book|last1=Winning|first1=Lisa|title=He Texted the ultimate guide to decoding guys|date=15 April 2014|publisher=Simon & Schuster|location=North America|isbn=9781476739298|url=http://www.simonandschuster.com/authors/Lisa-Winning/411721187|accessdate=29 December 2017}}</ref> consisting of the site's most popular user generated content.
Alongside Margaret Zhang, [[Roxy Jacenko]], Tammy Barton, and [[Marita Cheng]], Winning was recognized by Startup Daily as number 15 of the top 50 female entrepreneurs aged under 40 in Australian technology <ref>{{cite web|title=The Top 50 Female Entrepreneurs Under 40 - Startup Daily|url=https://www.slideshare.net/JadeGreen3/the-top-50-female-entrepreneurs-under-40-startup-daily-48464377|website=StartupDaily|publisher=Startup Daily|accessdate=3 January 2018}}</ref>.
HeTexted was described as "an incredibly addicting formula<ref>{{cite news|title=Is HeTexted.com Taking CrowdSourcing to a Whole New Level|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/home/is-hetexted-com-taking-crowdsourcing-to-a-whole-new-level/|publisher=Digital Trends|date=9 October 2012}}</ref>", and Winning's unique idea to crowdsource advice for Millennials was covered by ABC Newsâ Good Morning America <ref>{{cite news|title=HeTexted.com: Strangers Analyze Text Messages from Your Date|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Technology/hetextedcom-strangers-analyze-text-messages-date/story?id=17466587|accessdate=29 December 2017|agency=ABC News Good Morning America|date=13 October 2012}}</ref>, CNN <ref>{{cite news|title=Stop being a masochist online: Putting a date's ambiguous texts up for mass voting|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2012/10/10/tech/social-media/netiquette-masochist-online/index.html|accessdate=29 December 2017|agency=CNN|date=October 10, 2012}}</ref>, The Wall Street Journalâs All Things Digital <ref>{{cite news|title=With HeTexted, Others Can Judge Your Dateâs Text Messages|url=http://allthingsd.com/20121003/with-hetexted-others-can-judge-your-dates-text-messages/|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=The Wall Street Journal|date=October 3, 2012}}</ref>, The Guardian <ref>{{cite news|title=Modern romance for Generation Text, showcased on HeTexted.com|url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/oct/11/hetexted-com-generation-text-romance|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=The Guardian|date=11 October 2012}}</ref>, and Today <ref>{{cite news|title=He texted WHAT? Strangers analyze your love life|url=https://www.today.com/money/he-texted-what-strangers-analyze-your-love-life-1C6341928|accessdate=29 December 2017|agency=Today.com|date=October 9, 2012}}</ref>.
Winning raised venture capital from Silicon Valley investors including [[Dave McClure]] of [[500 Startups]] <ref>{{cite news|title=With Dave McClure Becoming An Investor, HeTexted could become the dominant player in the situation based advice space|url=http://www.startupdaily.net/2014/12/dave-mcclure-becoming-investor-hetexted-become-dominant-player-situation-based-advice-space/|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=Startup Daily|date=17 December 2014}}</ref>, and is represented by US talent agency [[William Morris Endeavor]], allowing the tech startup to expand into other media categories including books and film<ref>{{cite news|title=HeTexted, She's Monetising, Aussie Lisa Winning is Raising $900K to Expand|url=http://www.afr.com/leadership/entrepreneur/hetexted-shes-monetising-aussie-lisa-winning-is-raising-900k-to-expand-relationship-advice-platform-20140922-jy9up|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=Australian Financial Review|date=23 September 2014}}</ref>.
She has been interviewed by Good Morning America <ref>{{cite news|title=HeTexted Website Helps Women Decipher Text Messages Men|url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/video/hetexted-website-helps-women-decipher-text-messages-men-17516537|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=Good Morning America}}</ref>, the Huffington Post <ref>{{cite news|title=HeTexted: New Website Helps Decipher Your Date's Text Messages|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com.au/entry/hetexted-new-website-help_n_1948226|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=The Huffington Post|date=September 2012}}</ref>, CNBC <ref>{{cite news|title=Crowdsourcing love advice|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2015/12/17/crowdsourcing-love-advice.html|accessdate=29 December 2017|agency=CNBC Power Pitch|date=17 December 2015}}</ref>, the Evening Standard <ref>{{cite news|title=How to decode his SMS with HeTexted|url=https://www.standard.co.uk/lifestyle/london-life/how-to-decode-his-sms-with-hetexted-9237924.html|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=The Evening Standard|date=4 April 2014}}</ref> and recognized by Marie Claire for International Women's Day <ref>{{cite news|title=Does He Fancy Me? The New Genius Dating Advice Site|url=http://www.marieclaire.co.uk/life/sex-and-relationships/read-our-exclusive-interview-with-hetexted-founder-lisa-winning-128032|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=Marie Claire|date=March 6, 2013}}</ref>.
Winning has contributor columns with Forbes<ref>{{cite news|title=Contributor: Lisa Winning|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/lisawinning/#1b9cec5818ea|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=Forbes|date=November 2017}}</ref> writing about technology and startups. She previously contributed to Virgin.<ref>{{cite news|title=Lisa Winning Tech & media entrepreneur|url=https://www.virgin.com/person/lisa-winning|accessdate=29 December 2017|publisher=Virgin.com|date=April 2016}}</ref>

{{multiple image | a header = | header_align = left/right/centre | footer = A bronze Chinese [[crossbow]] trigger mechanism with a butt plate (the wooden components have since eroded and disappeared), inlaid with silver, from either the late [[Warring States period]] (403â256 BC) or the early [[Han Dynasty]] (202 BC â AD 220) | footer_align = left | image1 = Warring States or Western Han crossbow.jpg | width1 = 150 | image2 = Warring States or Western Han crossbow2.jpg | width2 = 150 }} {{History of science and technology in China}}
[[History of Science and Technology in China|China]] has been the source of many [[innovations]], [[scientific]] [[discovery (observation)|discoveries]] and [[invention]]s.<ref>[[Joseph Needham]], ''[[Science and Civilisation in China]]'', 1954â2008, Cambridge University Press</ref> This includes the ''[[Four Great Inventions]]'': [[papermaking]], the [[compass]], [[gunpowder]], and [[History of typography in East Asia|printing]] (both [[Woodblock printing|woodblock]] and [[movable type]]). The list below contains these and other inventions in China attested by archaeological or historical evidence.
The historical region now known as China experienced a [[History of science and technology in China|history]] involving [[mechanics]], [[hydraulics]] and [[mathematics]] applied to [[horology]], [[metallurgy]], [[astronomy]], [[agriculture]], [[engineering]], [[music theory]], [[Artisan|craftsmanship]], [[Maritime history|naval architecture]] and [[warfare]]. By the [[Warring States period]] (403â221 BC), inhabitants of the Warring States had advanced metallurgic technology, including the [[blast furnace]] and [[cupola furnace]], while the [[finery forge]] and [[Puddling (metallurgy)|puddling process]] were known by the [[Han Dynasty]] (202 BCâAD 220). A sophisticated economic system in imperial China gave birth to inventions such as [[Banknote|paper money]] during the [[Song Dynasty]] (960â1279). The invention of gunpowder during the mid 9th century led to an array of inventions such as the [[fire lance]], [[land mine]], [[naval mine]], [[hand cannon]], exploding cannonballs, multistage [[rocket]] and [[Huolongjing#Fire arrows and rockets|rocket bombs with aerodynamic wings and explosive payloads]]. With the navigational aid of the 11th century compass and ability to steer at high sea with the 1st century sternpost [[Rudder#China|rudder]], premodern Chinese sailors sailed as far as [[East Africa]].<ref>Bowman (2000), 104â105.</ref><ref>Levathes (1994), 37â38.</ref><ref>Hsu (1988), 96.</ref> In water-powered clockworks, the premodern Chinese had used the [[escapement]] mechanism since the 8th century and the endless power-transmitting [[chain drive]] in the 11th century. They also made large mechanical puppet theaters driven by [[waterwheel]]s and [[spoke|carriage wheels]] and wine-serving [[automaton]]s driven by paddle wheel boats.
The contemporaneous [[Peiligang culture|Peiligang]] and [[Pengtoushan culture]]s represent the oldest [[List of Neolithic cultures of China|Neolithic cultures of China]] and were formed around 7000 BC.<ref name="bellwood 2005 106">Bellwood (2006), 106.</ref> Some of the first inventions of Neolithic China include semilunar and rectangular stone knives, stone [[Hoe (tool)|hoes]] and spades, the cultivation of [[Foxtail millet|millet]], rice, and the [[soybean]], the refinement of [[sericulture]], the building of [[rammed earth]] structures with [[lime (material)|lime]]-plastered house floors, the [[Chinese ceramics|creation of pottery]] with cord-mat-basket designs, the creation of pottery tripods and pottery steamers and the development of ceremonial vessels and [[scapulimancy]] for purposes of [[divination]].<ref>Needham (2004) p201.</ref><ref name="bray 1978 24">Bray (1978), 24â26.</ref> The British sinologist Francesca Bray argues that the domestication of the [[ox]] and [[domestic buffalo|buffalo]] during the [[Longshan culture]] (c. 3000âc. 2000 BC) period, the absence of Longshan-era [[irrigation]] or high-yield crops, full evidence of Longshan cultivation of dry-land cereal crops which gave high yields "only when the soil was carefully cultivated," suggest that the [[plough]] was known at least by the Longshan culture period and explains the high agricultural production yields which allowed the rise of Chinese civilization during the [[Shang Dynasty]] (c. 1600âc. 1050 BC).<ref>Bray (1978), 27â28.</ref> Later inventions such as the [[Seed drill|multiple-tube seed drill]] and [[Heavy plough|heavy moldboard iron plough]] enabled China to sustain a much larger population through greater improvements in agricultural output.
For the purposes of this list, inventions are regarded as technological firsts developed in China, and as such does not include foreign technologies which the Chinese acquired through contact, such as the [[windmill]] from the [[Middle East]] or the [[telescope]] from [[early modern Europe]]. It also does not include technologies developed elsewhere and later invented separately by the Chinese, such as the [[odometer]], [[water wheel]], and [[chain pump]]. Scientific, mathematical or [[List of Chinese discoveries|natural discoveries]], changes in minor concepts of design or style and artistic innovations do not appear on the list.
{{Compact ToC|side=yes|custom1=Four Great Inventions|custom2=Pre-Shang|custom3=Shang and later|custom4=Modern (1912-present)|nobreak=no|refs=yes|seealso=yes}}
==Four Great Inventions== {{Main|Four Great Inventions}} The following is a list of the ''Four Great Inventions''âas designated by [[Joseph Needham]] (1900â1995), a British scientist, author and [[sinologist]] known for his research on the history of Chinese science and technology.<ref>Needham (1986), Volume 4, Part 1, p. 290.</ref>
[[File:Chinese hemp paper western han.jpg|thumb|Fragments of [[hemp]] wrapping paper dated to the reign of [[Emperor Wu of Han]] (141â87 BC)]] [[File:Jingangjing.jpg|thumb|The ''[[Diamond Sutra]]'', the oldest printed book, published in AD 868 during the Tang Dynasty (618â907)]]
===Paper=== :''This sub-section is about paper making; for the writing material first used in [[ancient Egypt]], see [[papyrus]].'' Although it is recorded that the Han Dynasty (202 BC â AD 220) court eunuch [[Cai Lun]] (50 AD â AD 121) invented the pulp [[papermaking]] process and established the use of new materials used in making [[paper]], ancient padding and wrapping paper artifacts dating to the 2nd century BC have been found in China, the oldest example of pulp papermaking [[Chinese cartography|being a map]] from [[Fangmatan]], [[Tianshui]];<ref>Buisseret (1998), 12.</ref> by the 3rd century, paper as a writing medium [[History of the Han Dynasty#Reign of Wu|was in widespread use]], replacing traditional but more expensive writing mediums such as strips of [[bamboo]] rolled into threaded scrolls, strips of [[silk]], wet [[clay tablet]]s hardened later in a furnace, and wooden tablets.<ref>Needham (1985), Volume 5, Part 1, 1â2, 40â41, 122â123, 228.</ref><ref name="bowman 2000 594">Bowman (2000), 594.</ref><ref name="tom 1989 99">Tom (1989), 99.</ref><ref name="day mcneil 122">Day & McNeil (1996), 122.</ref><ref>Cotterell (2004), 11â13.</ref> The earliest known piece of paper with writing on it was discovered in the ruins of a Chinese watchtower at Tsakhortei, [[Alxa League]], where Han Dynasty troops had deserted their position in AD 110 following a [[Xiongnu]] attack.<ref>Cotterell (2004), 11.</ref> In the paper making process established by Cai in 105, a boiled mixture of [[Morus (plant)|mulberry tree]] bark, hemp, old linens and fish nets created a pulp that was pounded into paste and stirred with water; a wooden frame sieve with a mat of sewn reeds was then dunked into the mixture, which was then shaken and then dried into sheets of paper that were bleached under the exposure of sunlight; K.S. Tom says this process was gradually improved through leaching, polishing and glazing to produce a smooth, strong paper.<ref name="tom 1989 99"/><ref name="day mcneil 122"/>
===Printing===
[[File:Yuan dynasty banknote with its printing plate 1287.jpg|thumb|left|Yuan dynasty banknote with its printing wood plate 1287.]]
:''For the separate invention of movable type printing in medieval Europe, see [[printing press]] and [[Johannes Gutenberg]]''. '''[[Woodblock printing]]''': The earliest specimen of woodblock printing is a single-sheet ''[[dharani]]'' sutra in [[Sanskrit]] that was printed on hemp paper between 650 and 670 AD; it was unearthed in 1974 from a Tang tomb near [[Xi'an]].<ref>Pan (1997), 979â980.</ref> A Korean miniature ''dharani'' Buddhist [[sutra]] discovered in 1966, bearing [[Chinese characters of Empress Wu|extinct Chinese writing characters]] used only during the reign of China's only self-ruling empress, [[Wu Zetian]] (r.690â705), is dated no earlier than 704 and preserved in a [[Unified Silla|Silla Korean]] temple [[stupa]] built in 751.<ref>Needham and Tsien (1985), Volume 5, Part 1, 149â150.</ref> The first printed periodical, the [[Kaiyuan Za Bao]] was made available in AD 713. However, the earliest known book printed at regular size is the ''[[Diamond Sutra]]'' made during the [[Tang Dynasty]] (618â907), a 5.18 m (17 ft) long scroll which bears the date 868 AD.<ref name="needham volume 5 part 1 151">Needham (1986), Volume 5, Part 1, 151.</ref> Joseph Needham and [[Tsien Tsuen-hsuin]] write that the cutting and printing techniques used for the [[Chinese calligraphy|delicate calligraphy]] of the ''Diamond Sutra'' book are much more advanced and refined than the miniature ''dharani'' sutra printed earlier.<ref name="needham volume 5 part 1 151"/>
[[File:Chinese movable type 1313-ce.png|left|thumb|An illustration published in [[Wang Zhen (official)|Wang Zhen's]] ([[floruit|fl.]] 1290â1333) book of AD 1313 showing [[movable type]] characters arranged by rhyme scheme in round table compartments]]
'''[[Movable type]]''': The polymath scientist and official [[Shen Kuo]] (1031â1095) of the Song Dynasty (960â1279) was the first to describe the process of movable type printing in his ''[[Dream Pool Essays]]'' of 1088. He attributed the innovation of reusable fired clay characters to a little-known artisan named [[Bi Sheng]] (990â1051).<ref>Needham, Volume 5, Part 1, 201â202.</ref><ref name="gernet 1996 335">Gernet (1996), 335.</ref><ref name="bowman 2000 599">Bowman (2000), 599.</ref><ref name="day mcneil 70">Day & McNeil (1996), 70.</ref> Bi had experimented with wooden type characters, but their use was not perfected until 1297 to 1298 with the model of the official [[Wang Zhen (official)|Wang Zhen]] (fl. 1290â1333) of the [[Yuan Dynasty]] (1271â1368), who also arranged written characters by rhyme scheme on the surface of round table compartments.<ref name="gernet 1996 335"/><ref>Needham (1986), Volume 5, Part 1, 205â207.</ref> It was not until 1490 with the printed works of [[Hua Sui]] (1439â1513) of the [[Ming Dynasty]] (1368â1644) that the Chinese perfected metal movable type characters, namely [[bronze]].<ref>Needham, Volume 5, Part 1, 212.</ref><ref name="bowman 2000 601"/> The [[Qing Dynasty]] (1644â1912) scholar Xu Zhiding of [[Tai'an]], [[Shandong]] developed [[vitreous enamel]] movable type printing in 1718.<ref>Needham (1986), Volume 5, Part 1, 203.</ref>
===Gunpowder=== [[File:Chinese Gunpowder Formula.JPG|thumb|Earliest known written formula for gunpowder, from the ''[[Wujing Zongyao]]'' of 1044 AD.]] Evidence of [[gunpowder]]'s first use in China comes from the [[Tang dynasty]] (618â907).<ref>Needham, Volume 5, Part 7, 8â9, 80â82.</ref> The earliest known recorded [[History of gunpowder|recipes for gunpowder were written]] by Zeng Gongliang, Ding Du and Yang Weide in the ''[[Wujing Zongyao]]'', a military manuscript compiled in 1044 during the Song Dynasty (960â1279). Its gunpowder formulas describe the use of [[Incendiary device|incendiary bombs]] launched from [[catapult]]s, thrown down from [[Chinese city wall|defensive walls]], or lowered down the wall by use of iron chains operated by a swape lever.<ref>Needham (1986), Volume 5, Part 7, 70â73, 120â124.</ref><ref name="gernet 1996 311">Gernet (1996), 311.</ref><ref>Day & McNeil (1996), 785.</ref> Bombs launched from [[trebuchet]] catapults mounted on [[forecastle]]s of naval ships ensured the victory of Song over [[Jin Dynasty (1115-1234)|Jin forces]] at the [[Battle of Caishi]] in 1161, while the Mongol Yuan Dynasty (1271â1368) [[:Image:Mooko-Suenaga.jpg|used gunpowder bombs]] during their [[Mongol invasions of Japan|failed invasion of Japan]] in 1274 and 1281.<ref name="gernet 1996 311"/> During the 13th and 14th centuries, gunpowder formulas became more potent (with [[nitrate]] levels of up to 91%) and gunpowder weaponry more advanced and deadly, as evidenced in the Ming Dynasty (1368â1644) military manuscript ''[[Huolongjing]]'' compiled by [[Jiao Yu]] (fl. 14th to early 15th century) and [[Liu Bowen]] (1311â1375). It was completed in 1412, a long while after Liu's death, with a preface added by the Jiao in its [[Nanyang, Henan|Nanyang]] publication.<ref>Needham (1986), Volume 5, Part 7, 24â25, 345â346.</ref>
===Compass=== [[File:Antic chinese Compass.jpg|thumb|A model in [[Kaifeng]] of a Chinese ladle-and-bowl type [[compass]] used for [[geomancy]] in the Han Dynasty (202 BC â 220 AD); the historical authenticity of the model has been questioned by [[Li Shu-hua]] (1954).<ref name="Li Shu-hua 176, 180">Li Shu-hua (1954), 176, 180.</ref>]]
Although an ancient [[hematite]] artifact from the [[Olmec]] era in [[Mexico]] dating to roughly 1000 BC indicates the possible use of the [[lodestone]] [[compass]] long before it was described in China, the Olmecs did not have [[iron]] which the Chinese would discover could be magnetised by contact with lodestone.<ref>Carlson (1975), 753â760.</ref> Descriptions of lodestone attracting iron were made in the ''Guanzi'', ''[[Lushi Chunqiu|Master Lu's Spring and Autumn Annals]]'' and ''[[Huainanzi]]''.<ref>Blanc (1985), 125, 128, 132â133, 136.</ref><ref>Knoblock (2001), 218.</ref><ref>Rickett (1998), 426.</ref> The Chinese by the Han Dynasty (202 BC â 220 AD) began using north-south oriented lodestone ladle-and-bowl shaped [[compass]]es for [[divination]] and [[geomancy]] and not yet for [[navigation]].<ref>Carlson (1975), 755.</ref><ref name="gernet 1962 77">Gernet (1962), 77.</ref><ref>Tom (1989), 98â99.</ref> The ''[[Lunheng]]'', written by Han dynasty writer, scientist, and philosopher [[Wang Chong]] (27 â c. 100 AD) stated in chapter 52: "This instrument resembles a spoon and when it is placed on a plate on the ground, the handle points to the south".<ref>Lacheisserie (2005), 5</ref><ref>Aczel (2002), 80.</ref> There are, however, another two references under chapter 47 of the same text to the attractive power of a magnet according to Needham (1986),<ref>Needham (1986), Volume 4, Part 1, see 261 footnote. f for ch. 52 on ladle and 232 footnote. d for ch. 47 on magnet (c.f. ''Lunheng'' [[:zh:s:è®ºè¡¡/52|ch. 52]] & [[:zh:s:è®ºè¡¡/47|ch. 47]]).</ref> but Li Shu-hua (1954) considers it to be lodestone, and states that there is no explicit mention of a magnet in ''Lunheng''.<ref name="Li Shu-hua 176, 180"/> The Chinese polymath [[Shen Kuo]] (1031â1095) of the Song Dynasty (960â1279) was the first to accurately describe both [[magnetic declination]] (in discerning [[true north]]) and the [[History of the compass|magnetic needle compass]] in his ''[[Dream Pool Essays]]'' of 1088, while the Song dynasty writer [[Zhu Yu (author)|Zhu Yu]] (fl. 12th century) was the first to mention use of the compass specifically for navigation at sea in his book published in 1119.<ref name="bowman 2000 599"/><ref name="gernet 1962 77"/><ref>Sivin (1995), III, 21â22.</ref><ref>Needham (1986), Volume 4, Part 1, 279.</ref><ref>Elisseeff (2000), 296.</ref><ref>Gernet (1996), 328.</ref><ref name="day mcneil 1996 636"/> Even before this, however, the ''[[Wujing Zongyao]]'' military manuscript compiled by 1044 described a [[thermoremanence]] compass of heated iron or [[steel]] shaped as a fish and placed in a bowl of water which produced a weak magnetic force via [[remanence]] and induction; the ''Wujing Zongyao'' recorded that it was used as a pathfinder along with the mechanical [[south-pointing chariot]].<ref>Needham (1986), Volume 4, Part 1, 252.</ref><ref>Sivin (1995), III, 21.</ref>

==Pre-Shang== Inventions which originated in [[List of Neolithic cultures of China|what is now China during the Neolithic age]] and prehistoric [[List of Bronze Age sites in China|Bronze Age]] are listed in alphabetical order below. <!-- Unreferenced additions will be removed --> [[File:Chinesericewine.jpg|thumb|Chinese alcoholic [[rice wine]] containers.]] * '''[[Alcoholic beverage]]''' and the process of '''[[Fermentation in food processing|fermentation]]''': The earliest archaeological evidence of [[fermentation]] and the consumption of alcoholic beverages was discovered in [[neolithic]] China dating from 7000â6600 BC. Examination and analysis of ancient pottery jars from the neolithic village of [[Jiahu]] in [[Henan]] province in northern China revealed fermented residue left behind by the alcoholic beverages they once contained. According to a study published in the ''[[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America|Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]]'', chemical analysis of the residue revealed that the fermented drink was made from fruit, rice and [[honey]].<ref name="mcgovern">{{Cite journal |last1=McGovern |first1=P.
