{{notability|Companies|date=August 2016}} [[Image:Revox logo.svg|thumb|ReVox corporate logo]] '''ReVox''' is a brand name, registered by [[Studer]] on March 27, 1951, for [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[audio equipment]].<ref name=Revox1948to1979>{{cite book|title=Revox 1948-1979: From prototype to world exports.|date=1979|publisher=Willi Studer Fabrik fur elektronische Apparate|location=Regensdorf|edition=1}}</ref>
The first Studer-designed tape recorders were branded Dynavox. After the first production series of Dynavox recorders, a new marketing company was formed in 1950 called ELA AG. Revox was adopted as the brand name for amateur recorders, while the professional machines retained the Studer name.<ref name="Revox1948to1979" />
The first Revox-branded tape recorder was the T26, in 1952, successor to the Dynavox 100.
The T26 was also made available as a radio-recorder combination unit. 2500 T26 recorders were made, priced at 1395.00 [[Swiss franc]]s.<ref name="Revox1948to1979" />
The A36, the first 36 series recorder. became available in 1954. Unusual features for the time were pushbutton [[solenoid]] [[Tape transport|transport]] operations and a direct-drive [[Capstan (tape recorder)|capstan]] with no belts or idler wheels. The B36 of 1956 was the first 3-head model, the D36 of 1960 was the first stereo model.
The company moved to [[LÃ¶ffingen]], [[West Germany]], in 1966, due to labour issues in Switzerland. But the building of a second factory was started in [[Regensdorf]], Switzerland in 1967 - to open in 1968.<ref name="Revox1948to1979" />
In 1967 the 36-series tape recorders ended with the G36, and were superseded by the transistorised A77 with a servo-controlled direct drive capstan. Over 80,000 36-series recorders had been manufactured. The A77 was complemented by an integrated amplifier (A78) and FM tuner (A76). The start of the 1980s saw the introduction of the "B7xx" series of high fidelity components, which was in turn replaced by the B2xx series in the mid 1980s. The B2xx series was versatile (the B250 amplifier offering 10 signal inputs, each with automatic sensitivity calibration) and feature-rich, all components containing microprocessors. Contrastingly, the "H" line, with "H" standing for Human, went to the opposite extreme, with minimalist control interfaces: several "H" components having only three buttons.
In 1990 Willi Studer sold the Studer Revox Group to Motor-Columbus AG, including all subsidiary companies. In 1991, Motor-Columbus split the Studer Revox Group into Studer (Pro), Revox (HiFi) and a Manufacturing-division. Motor-Columbus sold several subsidiaries and plants.
The extensive reorganization culminated in the sale of the Studer Group to Harman International Inc., in March 1994. The Revox Group was excluded and sold to private investors. On March 17, 1994, Harman International Industries completed its acquisition and acquired from Motor-Columbus AG 100% of Studer Revox AG. Harman paid 100 Swiss Francs (approximately US $70.00) for all of the issued and outstanding stock in Studer Revox. Harman assumed post-acquisition indebtedness of Studer Revox of approximately 23 million Swiss Francs (approximately US $16 million).<ref name="Harmanreport">{{cite web|title=Securities and Exchange Commission, Washington, D.C., 20549 â form 8-K/A â Current Report|url=http://investor.harman.com/secfiling.cfm?filingid=800459-94-9&cik=800459|website=Harman Intl - Amended Current Report:|publisher=Harman International Industries, Incorporated}}</ref>
The founder of Revox, Willi Studer, died on March 1, 1996.<ref name="JourAES_55_4">{{cite journal|last1=Siegenthaler|first1=Marcel|title=In Memoriam: Willi Studer|journal=Journal of the Audio Engineering Society|volume=55|issue=5|page=435|url=http://www.aes.org/aeshc/docs/jaes.obit/JAES_V44_5_PG435.pdf}}</ref>
The company logo is the word "REVOX" in capitals, with a "V" larger than the other letters; when printed in fixed-size type, the mixed-case spelling "ReVox" is sometimes used, but in all older and most newer references the name is shown as "Revox".
[[Image:Revox-reel-to-reel.JPG|thumb|right|Revox PR99 Mk II, a 1/4 inch tape recorder. Produced from about 1985.]] Many consider ReVox [[open-reel]] tape recorders to be [[high-end audio]] equipment. The most famous of these are the G36 (valve type), A77 (solid state with [[relay]] controls) and B77 (solid state with logic control and direct-drive). The A700 was the top of the line 1970s machine with 3-speed quartz PLL capstan, or, like the B77 which appeared in 1979, variable tape speed from 2.5 to 22.5 inches per second. Pictured to the right is the PR99 Mk2, a variant of the B77 for professional users, differing from the B77 in having balanced line in/out, and a real-time counter and auto-locator. The PR99 series was superseded by the C270 series, available also in multi-track formats (C274, C278).
Revox also produced well-regarded cassette tape recorders, notably the B710 and later the B215, which used the same transport and substantially the same electronics as the more expensive Studer A710 and Studer A721, respectively. It is worth noting that the Revox H11 and C115 cassette recorders are not true Revox or Studer products, but rebadged Philips Model FC60. As such, they do not meet the exacting performance standards of the B710, B215 and H1 which are Studer designed and built.
In the same fashion, the Revox B225 and B226 compact disc players were very heavily based on the Studer A725 and A727 professional CD players. Likewise, the Revox FM tuners were almost identical to the Studer professional models. A limited run of the B226 CD player was issued to celebrate Studer's 40th anniversary. Dubbed 'The Signature', it featured a black [[faceplate (housing)|faceplate]] (in contrast to the then silver (anodized aluminium) B226) and used the high performance Silver Crown version of the Philips TDA1541 DAC, which later featured in non-Signature B226-S versions.
Revox was one of the first manufacturers to market a plasma television set, the model E542 in 1999. Before that, they commissioned Loewe to manufacture a limited number of models of S-VHS and VHS video cassette recorders and CRT television sets branded with the Revox name. A DVD player bearing the Revox name (model S27) was built by the French company Micromega.
== Current technology ==
In 2002, Revox introduced with the Re:system M51 a modular audio video system in the market. This system can provide up to 32 rooms in 4 different listening zones with music. Different modules allow the user to select which sources he would like to use in his home, available sources (modules) for the M51 and M10 are amongst others FM-tuner, SAT-radio, Internet-radio, Multiroom, Audio server and also Audio streams. Solutions are available for all imaginable application possibilities up to the control via Apple products with the corresponding Apps. The operation of Multiroom require the availability of the corresponding Multiroom module and small amplifiers of the type M219 in the remote rooms. Also the first audio server of the company, the Revox M57, was perfectly in line with the Multiroom concept.
The M51 MKII is available with two different amplifiers. The analogue version performs 5 x 60 Watt sinus, the digital Class-D-amplifier 5 x 200 Watt sinus.
The M-series was extended in 2006 by the M10, a 19â rack solution as central nerve and source centre and in 2010 by the M100, an audiophile Hifi-stereo amplifier with 2 x 200 Watt sinus power, FM-tuner and DVD-drive in an extremely compact housing. For the models M10 and M51, the latter is currently available in version MKII, the insertable modules are identical. For the M100 the modules, except for Multiroom, are offered as pluggable supplementations to the basic model.
In the Multiroom operation the control of the rooms is effected by wall control units of the type M217/M218, by the remote controls M207 or M208 or by Apps, which are momentarily only available for the iOS-operating system.
In addition to the pure Audio server M37 MKII the Multimedia server M117 was introduced in 2011. In 2012 Revox presented the new audiophile network receivers Revox Joy S120, S119 and S118.
The workmanship of the devices is typically for Revox on a very high level and is characterised by the selection of precious materials like aluminium and glass.
== Reel to reel revived == As of May 2016, Revox announced the re-introduction of a reel-to-reel tape player, to be released in the first quarter of 2017. Manufactured and developed in conjunction with HORCH HOUSE (a division of Lutz Precision k.s.), it will initially be a playback-only machine, with a recorder/reproducer to follow.<ref name="Horch">{{cite web|title=Project R2R|url=http://www.analogarts.net/project-r2r/|website=Horch House|accessdate=6 May 2016}}</ref>
== Loudspeakers ==
For more than 40 years, Revox has been producing loudspeakers. The first speaker of the brand Revox was the series 46 (1970), which was developed for the former HiFi system A77, A76 and A50. The AX- (1976), the BX- (1977) and the BR-series (1980) followed. All speakers were developed and manufactured in the Revox plant in Ewattingen / Black Forest.
Numerous other speakers went along with the company in the 1980s. The most famous speakers were the Symbol B (1983) as well as the first Revox active speaker Agora B (1986). A milestone in the speaker development was the two digital active speakers Scala 4.7 (1994) and Scala 3.6 (1996). 1980 also saw the introduction of the Triton, one of the first sub-woofer / satellite systems for home high fidelity. The Triton subwoofer comprised a 200 lb cabinet designed to also act as a piece of furniture on which the entire B7xx series (including B77) could stand.<ref name="prospektus1980">{{cite book|title=Studer Revox 80 prospektus|publisher=Revox ELA AG Division Export|location=Regensdorf|page=30}}</ref> The Triton system was superseded by the smaller and more compact Piccolo, and later the Power Cube, which was a Piccolo bass unit with built-in power amplifiers and optional remote control and multi-room controller.
In 1987, Revox acquired the rights to manufacture the Stereolith Duetto, a single-box stereo loudspeaker. Built in the shape of a triangular prism, the Duetto was designed to complement, in acoustics and appearance, the Piccolo bass unit (passive operation) or the Power Cube (active operation).
Todayâs Revox range includes a very comprehensive{{Clarify|date=December 2012}} speaker assortment. Classical three-way speakers such as the Prestige of the Re:sound G or Re:sound S series, medium and small speakers as well as a very comprehensive range of installation speakers, which come into operation especially in the multi-room field.
== In popular culture ==
In ''[[Chaplin (film)]]'' (1992), a Revox machine is being used in Charles Chaplin's sessions with his biographer.
The film [[Diva (1981 film)|Diva]] (1981) features Revox B700 series components as playback equipment for the bootleg operatic recording of the diva.
[[Derren Brown]], in his TV Show [[Trick of the mind]], convinces [[Simon Pegg]] that his ideal birthday present would be a BMX bike, by having a Revox B77 tape recorder playing in the room, and suggesting that the visual image of such a machine subliminally suggests a bicycle. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jTwCMX5sUQU Link to Video Clip]
In [[Deutschland 83]] (2015 TV series), Revox PR99 reel to reel recorders (among other brands) are used by East German authorities to covertly record Nato operations.
[[Robert Fripp]] used Revox machines to produce his [[Frippertronics]] recordings in the late 1970s onward, until he replaced the recorders with digital delays in the 1990s.

[[File:A depiction of needle.JPG|thumb|A sewing needle]]
A '''sewing needle''' ,for hand-sewing, is a long slender tool with a pointed tip at one end and a hole (or ''eye'') at the other. The earliest needles were made of [[bone]] or [[wood]]; modern ones are manufactured from high [[carbon steel]] wire and are [[nickel]]- or [[gold|18K gold]]-plated for corrosion resistance. The highest quality embroidery needles are plated with two-thirds [[platinum]] and one-third [[titanium alloy]]. Traditionally, needles have been kept in needle books or [[needlecase]]s which have become objects of adornment.<ref>{{cite web| url= http://www.collectorsweekly.com/sewing/needle-cases |title= Antique Sewing Needle Cases|publisher= Collectors Weekly |accessdate=2012-05-25}}</ref> Sewing needles may also be kept in an [[Ã©tui]], a small box that held needles and other items such as scissors, pencils and tweezers.<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.collectorsweekly.com/sewing/needle-cases |title= Antique Sewing Needle Cases|publisher= Collectors Weekly |accessdate=2012-05-25}}</ref>
==Types of hand sewing needles== [[File:Needles (for sewing).jpg|thumb|Needles used for hand sewing{{clarification needed|date=April 2018}}]] [[File:Sewing needle eye with thread.jpg|thumb|Thread through the eye of a No.5 sharp needle]] Hand sewing needles come in a variety of types/ classes designed according to their intended use and in a variety of sizes within each type.<ref>http://www.sewing.org/files/guidelines/22_110_hand_sewing_needle_guide.pdf</ref>
*Sharp Needles: used for general hand sewing; built with a sharp point, a round eye, and are of medium length. Those with a double-eyes are able to carry two strands of thread while minimizing fabric friction. *[[AppliquÃ©]]: These are considered another all-purpose needle for sewing, appliquÃ©, and patch work. *[[Embroidery]]: Also known as [[crewel embroidery|crewel]] needles; identical to sharps but have a longer eye to enable easier threading of multiple embroidery threads and thicker [[yarn]]s. *Betweens or [[Quilting]]: These needles are shorter than sharps, with a small rounded eye and are used for making fine stitches on heavy fabrics such as in tailoring, [[quilt]] making and other detailed handwork; note that some manufacturers also distinguish between quilting needles and quilting ''between'' needles, the latter being slightly shorter and narrower than the former. *Milliners: A class of needles generally longer than sharps, useful for [[Tack (sewing)|basting]] and [[pleat]]ing, normally used in [[Hatmaking|millinery]] work. *Easy- or Self-threading: Also called calyxeyed sharps, side threading, and spiral eye needles, these needles have an open slot into which a thread may easily be guided rather than the usual closed eye design. *[[Beading]]: These needles are very fine, with a narrow eye to enable them to fit through the centre of beads and sequins along with a long shaft to thread and hold a number of beads at a time. *Bodkin: Also called ballpoints, this is a long, thick needle with a ballpoint end and a large, elongated eye. They can be flat or round and are generally used for threading elastic, ribbon or tape through casings and lace openings. *[[Chenille fabric|Chenille]]: These are similar to [[Needlepoint|tapestry]] needles but with large, long eyes and a very sharp point to penetrate closely woven fabrics. Useful for [[ribbon]] embroidery. *[[Darning]]: Sometimes called finishing needles, these are designed with a blunt tip and large eye making them similar to tapestry needles but longer; yarn darners are the heaviest sub-variety. *[[Doll]]: Not designed for hand sewing at all, these needles are made long and thin and are used for soft sculpturing on dolls, particularly facial details. *[[Leather]]: Also known as glovers and as wedge needles, these have a triangular point designed to pierce leather without tearing it; often used on leather-like materials such as vinyl and plastic. *Sailmaker: Similar to leather needles, but the triangular point extends further up the shaft; designed for sewing thick canvas or heavy leather. *[[Tapestry]]: The large eye on these needles lets them to carry a heavier weight yarn than other needles, and their blunt tipâusually bent at a slight angle from the rest of the needleâallows them to pass through loosely woven fabric such as embroidery [[canvas]] or [[even-weave]] material without catching or tearing it; comes in a double-eyed version for use on a mounted frame and with two colors of thread. *[[Tatting]]: These are built long with an even thickness for their entire length, including at the eye, to enable thread to be pulled through the double stitches used in tatting. *[[Upholstery]]: These needles are heavy, long needles that may be straight or curved and are used for sewing heavy fabrics, upholstery work, tufting and for tying quilts; the curved variety is practical for difficult situations on furniture where a straight needle will not work Heavy duty 12" needles are used for repairing [[mattress]]es. Straight sizes: 3"-12" long, curved: 1.5"-6" long.
==Needle size==
Needle size is denoted by one or more numbers on the manufacturer's packet. The general convention for sizing of needles, like that of [[wire gauge]]s, is that within any given class of needle the length and thickness of a needle ''increases'' as the size number ''decreases''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Some Insight on Needles|url=http://www.pumpkinvinecorner.com/needleinfo.htm|website=www.pumpkinvinecorner.com|publisher=Pumpkinvine Corner|accessdate=26 January 2016}}</ref> For example, a size 9 needle will be thicker and longer than a size 12 needle. However, the needle sizes are not standardized and so a size 10 of one class may be (and in some cases actually is) either thinner or finer than a size 12 of another type. Where a packet contains a needle count followed by two size numbers such as "20 Sharps 5/10" the second set of numbers correspond to the range of sizes of needle within the packet, in this case typically ten sharps needles of size 5 and ten of size 10 (for a total of 20 needles). As another example, a packet labeled "16 Milliners 3/9" would contain 16 milliners needles ranging in sizes from 3 to 9.
==History==
===Prehistoric sewing needles===
[[File:Aiguille os 246.1 Global.jpg|thumb|right|upright=1.5|alt=|<Center> [[Magdalenian]], [[Gourdan-Polignan]] France - [[:fr:MusÃ©um de Toulouse|MusÃ©um of Toulouse]]</center>]] The first form of sewing was probably tying together animal skins using thorns and sharpened rocks as needles,<ref>{{cite web|title=Prehistoric Clothing|url=http://www.fashionencyclopedia.com/fashion_costume_culture/The-Ancient-World-Prehistoric/Prehistoric-Clothing.html|website=www.fashionencyclopedia.com|publisher=Fashion, Costume, and Culture: Clothing, Headwear, Body Decorations, and Footwear through the Ages|accessdate=26 January 2016}}</ref> with animal sinew or plant material as thread.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fairholt|first1=Frederick William|title=Costume in England: A History of Dress from the Earliest Period Until the Close of the Eighteenth Century|publisher=Chapman and Hall|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4mMBAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA5|language=en|year=1860}}</ref> The early limitation was the ability to produce a small enough hole in a needle matrix, such as a bone sliver, not to damage the material. Traces of this survive in the use of bodkins to make eyelet holes in fabric by separating rather than cutting the threads. A point that might be from a bone needle dates to 61,000 years ago and was discovered in [[Sibudu Cave]], [[South Africa]].<ref name="Backwell">{{cite journal | last1 = Backwell | first1 = L | last2 = d'Errico | first2 = F | last3 = Wadley | first3 = L | year = 2008 | title = Middle Stone Age bone tools from the Howiesons Poort layers, Sibudu Cave, South Africa | url = | journal = Journal of Archaeological Science | volume = 35 | issue = 6| pages = 1566â1580 | doi = 10.1016/j.jas.2007.11.006 }}</ref> A needle made from bird bone and attributed to archaic humans, [[Denisovan|the Denisovans]], is estimated to be around 50,000 years-old, was found in [[Denisova Cave]].<ref name="Siberian Times 2016">{{cite web|title=World's oldest needle found in Siberian cave that stitches together human history|url=http://siberiantimes.com/science/casestudy/news/n0711-worlds-oldest-needle-found-in-siberian-cave-that-stitches-together-human-history/|website=The Siberian Times|accessdate=5 September 2016|date=23 August 2016}}</ref> A bone needle, dated to the [[Aurignacian]] age (47000 to 41,000 years ago), was discovered in [[Potok Cave]] ({{lang-sl|PotoÄka zijalka}}) in the Eastern [[Karavanke]], Slovenia.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://av.zrc-sazu.si/pdf/59/Odar_AV_59.pdf |title=A Dufour Bladelet from PotoÄka zijalka (Slovenia) |first=BoÅ¡tjan |last=Odar |journal=ArheoloÅ¡ki vestnik |volume=59 |year=2008 |page=13}}</ref> Bone and ivory needles found in the Xiaogushan prehistoric site in [[Liaoning]] province date between 30,000 and 23,000 years old.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bone and Ivory Needles|url=http://humanorigins.si.edu/evidence/behavior/tools/late-tools/bone-and-ivory-needles|website=humanorigins.si.edu|publisher=The Smithsonian Institution's Human Origins Program|accessdate=25 January 2016}}</ref> Ivory needles were also found dated to 30,000 years ago at the [[Kostenki]] site in Russia.<ref>Hoffecker, J., Scott, J., [http://www.colorado.edu/news/r/b278a670675fd8d2ca0700cdc0e9d808.html ''Excavations In Eastern Europe Reveal Ancient Human Lifestyles''], University of Colorado at Boulder News Archive, March 21, 2002</ref> [[Flinders Petrie]] found copper needles at [[Naqada]], ranging from 4400 BC to 3000 BC.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Nunn|first1=John|last2=Rowling|first2=John|title=The Eye of the Needle in Predynastic Egypt|journal=The Journal of Egyptian Archaeology|date=2001|volume=87|pages=171|doi=10.2307/3822378|jstor=3822378}}</ref> Iron sewing needles were found at the [[Oppidum of Manching]],<ref>{{cite book|last1=Klieforth|first1=Alexander Leslie|last2=Munro|first2=Robert John|title=The Scottish Invention of America, Democracy and Human Rights: A History of Liberty and Freedom from the Ancient Celts to the New Millennium|publisher=University Press of America|isbn=9780761827917|page=27|url=https://books.google.com/?id=lkzbIDj6rvkC&lpg=PA27&dq=Oppidum%20of%20Manching%20iron%20needle&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q=sewing%20needles&f=false|accessdate=25 January 2016|language=en|year=2004}}</ref> dating to the third century BC.
===Ancient sewing needles=== [[File:Tibet.needlecase.JPG|thumb|Tibetan needle-case]]
A form of needle lace named [[nÃ¥lebinding]] seems to generally predate knitting and crochet by thousands of years, partly because it can use far shorter rough-graded threads than knitting does.
[[Indigenous peoples of the Americas|Native Americans]] were known to use sewing needles from natural sources. One such source, the [[agave]] plant, provided both the needle and the "thread." The agave leaf would be soaked for an extended period of time, leaving a pulp, long, stringy fibres and a sharp tip connecting the ends of the fibres. The "needle" is essentially what was the tip end of the leaf. Once the fibres dried, the fibres and "needle" could then be used to sew together for deer bones.
Sewing needles are an application of wire-making technology, which started to appear in the second millennium B.C. Some fine examples of Bronze Age gold torques are made of very consistent gold wire, which is more malleable than bronze. However, copper and bronze needles do not need to be as long: the eye can be made by turning the wire back on itself and [[Drawing (manufacturing)|redrawing]] it through the [[Die (manufacturing)|die]].
===Later sewing needles=== [[File:MODOHirsch.jpg|thumb|Metal container for sewing needles from the second half of the 20th century. From the [[Museo del Objeto del Objeto]] collection]]
The next major break-through in needle-making was the arrival of high-quality [[Steel|steel-making]] technology from China in the tenth century, principally in Spain in the form of the [[Blast furnace#Catalan_forges|Catalan furnace]], which soon extended to produce reasonably high quality steel in significant volumes. This technology later extended to Germany and France, although not significantly in England. England began creating needles in 1639 at [[Redditch]],<ref>{{cite web|title=History|url=http://www.redditch.com/history.html|website=Redditch.com|accessdate=26 January 2016}}</ref> creating the drawn-wire technique still in common use today.<ref>{{cite web|title=How Needles Are Made|url=http://www.jjneedles.com/pages.php?pageid=8|website=www.jjneedles.com|publisher=John James Needles}}</ref> About 1655, needle manufacturers were sufficiently independent to establish a Guild of Needlemakers in London, although Redditch remained the principal place of manufacture.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Kirkup|first1=J|title=The history and evolution of surgical instruments. V needles and their penetrating derivatives.|journal=Annals of the Royal College of Surgeons of England|date=January 1986|volume=68|issue=1|pages=29â33|pmid=3511834|pmc=2498196}}</ref> In Japan, [[Hari-Kuyo]], the Festival of Broken Needles, dates back to the 1600s.

[[File:LG Smart TV web browser.jpg|thumb|300px|LG Smart TV model 42LW5700-TA showing web browser, with on-screen keyboard active; unlike traditional TVs, a smart TV enables the viewer to interact with icons or images on the screen.]] A '''smart TV''' is a traditional [[television set]] with integrated [[Internet]] and interactive "[[Web 2.0]]" features which allows you to stream music and videos, browse the internet, and view photos. Smart TV is a [[technological convergence]] between computers and [[flatscreen television]] sets and [[set-top box]]es. Besides the traditional functions of television sets and set-top boxes provided through traditional [[broadcasting]] media, these devices can also provide [[Internet TV]], online [[interactive media]], [[over-the-top content]] (OTT), as well as [[video on demand|on-demand]] [[streaming media]], and [[home network]]ing access.<ref name="businessinsider1">{{cite web|author=Steve Kovach | url=http://www.businessinsider.com/what-is-a-smart-tv-2010-12 |title=What Is A Smart TV? |publisher=Businessinsider.com |date=December 8, 2010|accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Jeremy Toeman 41 |url=http://mashable.com/2010/10/20/connected-tv-content-not-apps/ |title=Why Connected TVs Will Be About the Content, Not the Apps |publisher=Mashable.com |date=October 20, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=https://techcrunch.com/2010/10/24/internet-tv-and-the-death-of-cable-tv-really/ |title=Internet TV and The Death of Cable TV, really |publisher=Techcrunch.com |date=October 24, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref>
Smart TV should not be confused with [[Internet TV]], [[IPTV]] or [[Web television]]. Internet TV refers to receiving television content over the Internet instead of traditional systems (terrestrial, cable and satellite) (although Internet itself is received by these methods). IPTV is one of the Internet television technology standards for use by television broadcasters. Web television is a term used for programs created by a wide variety of companies and individuals for broadcast on Internet TV.
In smart TVs, the operating system is preloaded or is available through the set-top box. The [[software application]]s or "apps" can be preloaded into the device, or updated or installed on demand via an [[application store|app store or marketplace]], in a similar manner to how the apps are integrated in modern [[smartphone]]s.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asianewsnet.net/home/news.php?id=13857 |title=Smart TV competition heats up market |publisher=Asianewsnet.net |accessdate=January 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120407111651/http://www.asianewsnet.net/home/news.php?id=13857 |archivedate=April 7, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koreaittimes.com/story/10855/smart-tv-shower-opens-smart-life |title=Smart TV Shower Opens Smart Life |publisher=Koreaittimes.com |date=October 7, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Chacksfield |first=Marc |url=http://www.techradar.com/news/television/intel-smart-tv-revolution-biggest-since-move-to-colour--688832 |title=Intel: Smart TV revolution 'biggest since move to colour' â The wonders of widgets? |publisher=Techradar.com |date=May 12, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/technology/content/may2010/tc20100520_211952.htm |title=Google, With Intel and Sony, Unveils Software for 'Smart' TVs |work=Bloomberg BusinessWeek |date=May 20, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|last=Katzmaier |first=David |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20015791-1.html |title=Poll: Smart TV or dumb monitor? |publisher=News.cnet.com |date=September 8, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref>
The technology that enables smart TVs is also incorporated in external devices such as set-top boxes and some [[Blu-ray]] players, [[game console]]s, [[digital media player]]s, [[hotel television systems]], smartphones, and other network-connected interactive devices that utilize television-type display outputs.<ref name="intel1">[http://www.intel.com/inside/smarttv/ Intel and Smart TV]. intel.com. Retrieved on November 11, 2010.</ref><ref name="gizmodo1">{{cite web|url=https://gizmodo.com/5827779/roku-2-same-old-same-old |title=Roku 2: Same Old (But Still Good), Same Old |publisher=Gizmodo.com |date=August 4, 2011 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref> These devices allow viewers to find and play videos, movies, TV shows, photos and other content from the Web, cable or satellite TV channel, or from a local storage device.
==Definition== [[File:SamsungSmartTV.JPG|thumb|Smart TVs on display]] A ''smart TV'' device is either a television set with integrated Internet capabilities or a set-top box for television that offers more advanced computing ability and connectivity than a contemporary basic television set. Smart TVs may be thought of as an [[information appliance]] or the [[computer system]] from a [[handheld computer]] integrated within a television set unit, as such a smart TV often allows the user to install and run more advanced applications or [[Plug-in (computing)|plugins/addons]] based on a specific platform. Smart TVs run a complete [[operating system]] or [[mobile operating system]] software providing a platform for application developers.<ref name="businessinsider1"/><ref name="wired1">{{cite news|author=<!--start post navigation--> Previous post Next post |url=https://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2010/09/android-holds-the-key-to-samsungs-smart-tv-plans/ |title=Android Holds the Key to Samsungâs Smart TV Plans |work=Wired |date=September 7, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref name="wired2">{{cite news|author=<!--start post navigation--> Previous post Next post |url=https://www.wired.com/gadgetlab/2010/05/google-introduces-google-tv/ |title=Google Introduces Google TV, New Android OS |work=Wired |date=May 20, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref>
Smart TV platforms or middleware have a public [[Software development kit]] (SDK) and/or [[Native development kit]] (NDK) for apps so that third-party developers can develop applications for it, and an [[Application store|app store]] so that the end-users can install and uninstall apps themselves. The public SDK enables third-party companies and other interactive application developers to âwriteâ applications once and see them [[write once, run anywhere|run successfully on any device]] that supports the smart TV platform or middleware architecture which it was written for, no matter who the hardware manufacturer is.
Smart TVs deliver content (such as photos, movies and music) from other computers or network attached storage devices on a network using either a [[Digital Living Network Alliance]] / [[Universal Plug and Play]] media server or similar service program like [[Windows Media Player]] or [[Network-attached storage]] (NAS), or via [[iTunes]]. It also provides access to Internet-based services including traditional broadcast TV channels, [[Catch-up tv|catch-up services]], [[video-on-demand]] (VOD), [[electronic program guide]], interactive advertising, personalisation, voting, games, [[social networking]], and other multimedia applications.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gigaom.com/video/google-tv-apps/ |title=A first look at Google TVâs new apps |publisher=Gigaom.com |date=September 15, 2011 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref> Smart TV enables access to movies, shows, video games, apps and more. Some of those apps include Netflix, [[Spotify]], YouTube, and Amazon.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.samsung.com/us/experience/smart-tv/|title=Samsung Smart TV - TV Has Never Been This Smart|website=Samsung Electronics America|access-date=September 30, 2016}}</ref>
==History== In the early 1980s, "intelligent" television receivers were introduced in Japan. The addition of an [[Large-scale integration|LSI]] chip with memory and a character generator to a television receiver enabled Japanese viewers to receive a mix of programming and information transmitted over spare lines of the broadcast television signal.<ref>Gene Gregory (1985), ''Japanese Electronics Technology, Enterprise and Innovation'', page 351, [[Japan Times]]</ref> A patent was published in 1994<ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/originalDocument?FT=D&date=19960510&DB=EPODOC&locale=en_EP&CC=FR&NR=2726670A1&KC=A1&ND=3 |title=espacenet â Original document |publisher=Worldwide.espacenet.com |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref> (and extended the following year)<ref>{{cite web|url=http://worldwide.espacenet.com/publicationDetails/biblio?CC=US&NR=5905521A&KC=A&FT=D&ND=7&date=19990518&DB=EPODOC |title=espacenet â Bibliographic data |publisher=Worldwide.espacenet.com |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref> for an "intelligent" television system, linked with data processing systems, by means of a digital or analog network. Apart from being linked to data networks, one key point is its ability to automatically download necessary software routines, according to a user's demand, and process their needs.
The mass acceptance of digital television in late 2000s and early 2010s greatly improved smart TVs. Major TV manufacturers have announced production of smart TVs only, for their middle-end to high-end TVs in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theverge.com/2015/1/5/7497383/sony-new-smart-tv-run-android-tv-ces-2015|title=All of Sony's new smart TVs run on Android TV|author=Dieter Bohn|publisher=Vox Media|work=The Verge|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/24117/20150103/ces-2015-new-samsung-smart-tvs-will-be-powered-by-tizen-os.htm|title=CES 2015: New Samsung Smart TVs Will Be Powered by Tizen OS|work=Tech Times|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnet.com/news/lg-to-show-off-webos-2-0-smart-tv-at-ces-2015/|title=LG to show off webOS 2.0 smart TV at CES 2015|publisher=CBS Interactive|work=CNET|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref> Smart TVs are expected to become the dominant form of television by the late 2010s. At the beginning of 2016, Nielsen reported that 29 percent of those with incomes over $75,000 a year had a smart TV.<ref>{{cite journal|title=CES 2016: Five Things to Watch|last=Winslow|first=George|work=[[Broadcasting & Cable]]|date=January 4, 2016|pages=10â14}}</ref>
==Typical features== [[File:LG Smart TV web browser.jpg|thumb|LG Smart TV using the web browser.]]
Smart TV devices also provide access to [[user-generated content]] (either stored on an external [[hard drive]] or in [[cloud storage]]) and to interactive services and Internet applications, such as YouTube, many using [[HTTP Live Streaming]] (also known as HLS) adaptive streaming.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2011/09/14/netgear-unveils-neotv-streaming-player-takes-another-shot-at-th/ |title=Netgear unveils NeoTV Streaming Player, takes another shot at the smart TV market |publisher=Engadget.com |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref> Smart TV devices facilitate the curation of traditional content by combining information from the Internet with content from TV providers. Services offer users a means to track and receive reminders about shows<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.geekwire.com/2011/buddytv-debuts-google-tv-app-ipad-iphone-link/ |title=BuddyTV debuts Google TV app, with iPad and iPhone link |publisher=GeekWire |date=October 28, 2011 |accessdate=July 12, 2012}}</ref> or sporting events,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/article/2012-01-08/aB.FJP7Z5bV0.html |title=Thuuz Android App for Google TV Gives DISH Customers Instant Alerts of Most Exciting Moments in Sports |publisher=Bloomberg |date=January 8, 2012 |accessdate=July 12, 2012}}</ref> as well as the ability to change channels for immediate viewing. Some devices feature additional interactive [[organic user interface]] / [[natural user interface]] technologies for [[navigation controls]] and other [[Humanâcomputer interaction|human interaction]] with a Smart TV, with such as [[second screen]] companion devices,<ref>https://techcrunch.com/2012/06/04/microsoft-introduces-second-screen-feature-xbox-smartglass/ Microsoft Introduces Second-Screen Feature, Xbox SmartGlass</ref><ref>http://mashable.com/2012/06/04/xbox-smartglass/ Xbox SmartGlass Brings the Second Screen to Games and Videos</ref> spatial [[gestures]] input like with [[Xbox Kinect]],<ref>{{cite web |first=Blake |last=Robinson |url= http://mashable.com/2010/11/04/last-fm-kinect/ |title= Last.fm Gesture Controls for Xbox Kinect |publisher= Mashable.com |date=November 4, 2010 |accessdate= October 19, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|first=Evan |last=Narcisse|url=http://kotaku.com/5866279/wave-hello-microsofts-requiring-kinect-functionality-for-all-future-apps-built-for-xbox-360 |title=Wave Hello: Microsoftâs Requiring Kinect Functionality for All Future Apps Built for Xbox 360 |publisher=Kotaku.com |date=December 8, 2011 |accessdate=March 12, 2012}}</ref> and even for [[speech recognition]] for [[natural language user interface]].<ref>http://appleinsider.com/articles/13/01/10/2013-smart-tvs-dismissed-as-not-that-smart-leaving-opportunity-for-apple 2013 smart TVs dismissed as 'not that smart,' leaving opportunity for Apple</ref> Smart TV develops new features to satisfy consumers and companies, such as new payment processes. LG and [[Paymentwall|PaymentWall]] have collaborated to allow consumers to access purchased apps, movies, games, and more using a remote control, laptop, tablet, or smartphone. This is intended for an easier and more convenient way for checkout.
==Platforms== {{See also|List of smart TV platforms and middleware software}}
Smart TV technology and software is still evolving, with both [[Proprietary software|proprietary]] and [[Open-source software|open source]] [[software framework]]s already available. These can run applications (sometimes available via an 'app store' [[digital distribution]] [[platform (computing)|platform]]), interactive on-demand media, personalized communications, and have social networking features.<ref>{{cite web|author= Devindra Hardawar |url=https://venturebeat.com/2010/12/08/why-your-tv-is-the-new-app-battleground/ |title=Why your TV is the new app battleground |publisher=Venturebeat.com |date=December 8, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/10132877 BBC News â Google launches smart TV service]. bbc.co.uk (May 20, 2010). Retrieved on November 11, 2010.</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Stan Schroeder 230 |url=http://mashable.com/2010/05/17/google-intel-sony-smart-tv/ |title=Google, Intel and Sony to Introduce Smart TV |publisher=Mashable.com |date=May 17, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialtimes.com/2010/05/opinion-will-googles-smart-tv-finally-bring-apps-and-web-browsing-to-the-living-room/ |title=Opinion: Will Googleâs Smart TV Finally Bring Apps and Web Browsing To The Living Room? |publisher=Socialtimes.com |date=May 17, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012}}</ref>
[[Android TV]], [[Boxee]], [[Firefox OS]], Frog, [[Google TV]], [[Horizon TV Asia|Horizon TV]], httvLink, [[Inview Technology|Inview]], [[Kodi (software)|Kodi Entertainment Center]], [[MeeGo]], Mediaroom, OpenTV, Opera TV, [[Plex (software)|Plex]], Roku, RDK(Reference Development Kit), Smart TV Alliance, ToFu Media Platform, [[Ubuntu TV]], and [[Yahoo! HbbTV, provided by the Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV association, CE-HTML, part of Web4CE, OIPF, part of HbbTV, and Tru2way are framework platforms managed by technology businesses. Current Smart TV platforms used by vendors are [[Amazon.com|Amazon]], [[Apple Inc.|Apple]], [[Google]], [[Haier]], [[Hisense]], [[Hitachi]], Insigna, LG, [[Microsoft]], [[Netgear]], Panasonic, [[Philips]], Samsung, [[Sharp Corporation|Sharp]], [[Sony]], [[TCL Corporation|TCL]], [[TiVo|TiVO]], [[Toshiba]], [[Sling Media]], and [[Western Digital]]. Sony, Panasonic, [[Samsung]], [[LG Corporation|LG]], and [[Roku|Roku TV]] are some platforms ranked under the best Smart TV platforms.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.techradar.com/news/television/6-best-smart-tv-platforms-in-the-world-today-1120795/5|title=The 5 best Smart TV platforms in the world 2016|newspaper=TechRadar|access-date=November 4, 2016}}</ref>
==Sales== {{Update|section|Statistics till mid 2018 is needed for this section.|date=October 2018}} According to a report from research group NPD In-Stat, in 2012 only about 12 million U.S. households had their Web-capable TVs connected to the Internet, although an estimated 25 million households owned a set with the built-in network capability. In-Stat predicted that by 2016, 100 million homes in North America and western Europe would be using television sets blending traditional programming with internet content.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/entertainmentnewsbuzz/2012/03/100-million-tvs-will-be-internet-connected-by-2016.html | title=100 Million TVs will have internet connections by 2016}}</ref>
The number of households using [[Over-the-top content|over-the-top]] television services has rapidly increased over the years. In 2015, 52% of U.S. households subscribed to [[Netflix]], [[List of Amazon.com products and services|Amazon Prime]], or [[Hulu Plus]]; 43% of pay-TV subscribers also used Netflix, and 43% of adults used some streaming [[video on demand]] service at least monthly. Additionally, 19% of Netflix subscribers shared their subscription with people outside of their households. Ten percent of adults at the time showed interest in [[HBO Now]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.multichannel.com/news/next-tv/56-us-homes-have-tv-connected-internet/390895|title=U.S. Connected-TV Penetration Passes 50% {{!}} Multichannel|website=www.multichannel.com|access-date=November 29, 2016}}</ref>
===By manufacturer=== {{Empty section|date=October 2018}} ===By platform=== {{Empty section|date=October 2018}}
==Use== ===Social networking=== {{See also|Social media and television}} Some smart TV platforms come prepackaged, or can be optionally extended, with social networking technology capabilities. The addition of social networking synchronization to smart TV and HTPC platforms may provide an interaction with both on-screen content and other viewers than is currently available to most televisions, while simultaneously providing a much more cinematic experience of the content than is currently available with most computers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc15.com/dpp/news/science_tech/tvs-get-smart-with-internet-access-in-2011 |title=TVs get smart with Internet access in 2011 |publisher=Abc15.com |date=August 23, 2010 |accessdate=January 17, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110707072843/http://www.abc15.com/dpp/news/science_tech/tvs-get-smart-with-internet-access-in-2011 |archivedate=July 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
===Advertising=== Some smart TV platforms also support [[interactive advertising]], [[addressable advertising]] with local advertising insertion and targeted advertising,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.engadget.com/2014/01/15/sky-adsmart-targeted-advertising/|title=Sky's AdSmart brings targeted advertising to your TV|author=Daniel Cooper|publisher=AOL|work=Engadget|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref> and other advanced advertising features such as [[ad telescoping]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iptvdictionary.com/IPTVDictionary-Ad-Telescoping-Definition.html|title=Ad Telescoping|publisher=|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref> using [[video on demand|VOD]] and [[Digital video recorder|DVR]], enhanced TV for consumer [[Call to action (marketing)|call-to-action]] and [[audience measurement]] solutions for ad campaign effectiveness.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nagra.com/dtv/company/newsroom/press-releases/article/?id=1195|title=Kudelski Group :: Notification|author=|date=|website=www.nagra.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nagra.com/media-center/press-releases/nagra-opentv-and-time-warner-cable-media-extend-advanced-advertising |title="NAGRA-OpenTV and Time Warner Cable Media Extend Advanced Advertising Partnership" March 5, 2012 - Cheseaux, Switzerland|publisher=|accessdate=September 10, 2016}}</ref> The marketing and trading possibilities offered by Smart TVs are sometimes summarized by the term [[t-commerce]]. Taken together, this [[Duplex (telecommunications)|bidirectional]] data flow means that smart TVs can be and are used for [[surveillance|clandestine observation]] of the owners.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-2513592/Is-TV-spying-YOU.html|title=Is your TV spying on YOU?}}</ref> Even in sets that are not configured off-the-shelf to do so, default security measures are often weak and will allow hackers to easily break into the TV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2013/08/02/samsung-smart-tv-hack/|title=Your Smart TV Could Be Hacked to Spy On You}}</ref>
===Security=== There is evidence that a smart TV is vulnerable to attacks. Some serious [[internet security|security]] bugs have been discovered, and some successful attempts to run [[malware|malicious code]] to get unauthorized access were documented on video. There is evidence that it is possible to gain [[Superuser|root access]] to the device, install malicious software, access and modify configuration information for a [[remote control]], remotely access and modify files on TV and attached USB drives, access camera and microphone.<ref name=NotSoSmart>{{cite web|last1=Niemietz|title=Not so Smart: On Smart TV Apps|url=http://nds.rub.de/media/nds/veroeffentlichungen/2015/08/31/SmartTvAttacks.pdf|publisher=International Workshop on Secure Internet of Things|accessdate=September 15, 2015|display-authors=etal}}</ref>.
There have also been concerns that [[hacker]]s may be able to remotely turn on the microphone or web-camera on a smart TV, being able to eavesdrop on private conversations. A common [[loop antenna]] may be set for a ''bi''directional transmission channel, capable of uploading data rather than only receiving. Since 2012, security researchers discovered a similar vulnerability present in more [[mass production|series]] of Smart Tvs, which allows hackers to get an external [[root access]] on the device<ref>{{cite news|url= https://www.computerworld.com.au/article/444399/samsung_tv_vulnerability_could_let_hacker_change_channel/|title= Samsung TV vulnerability could let a hacker change the channel|date= Dec 12, 2015|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20130306010836/https://www.computerworld.com.au/article/444399/samsung_tv_vulnerability_could_let_hacker_change_channel/|archive-date= March 6, 2013 |deadurl= }}</ref>.
Anticipating growing demand for an [[antivirus]] for a smart TV, some [[security software]] companies are already working with partners in digital TV field on the solution. At this writing it seems like there is only one antivirus for smart TVs available: 'Neptune', a cloud-based antimalware system developed by Ocean Blue Software in partnership with [[Sophos]]. However, antivirus company [[Avira]] has joined forces with digital TV testing company Labwise to work on software to protect against potential attacks.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://www.pctechbootcamp.com/can-your-smart-tv-get-a-virus/ | title=CAN YOUR SMART TV GET A VIRUS?}}</ref> The privacy policy for [[Samsung|Samsung's]] Smart TVs has been called [[Orwellian]] (a reference to [[George Orwell]] and the dystopian world of constant surveillance he depicted in ''[[1984 (novel)|1984]]''), and compared to [[Telescreen]]s because of eavesdropping concerns.<ref>{{Cite news | url= https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/gadgets-and-tech/news/samsungs-new-smart-tv-policy-allows-company-to-listen-in-on-users-10033012.html | title = Samsung smart TV policy allows company to listen in on users | work= The Independent | date = February 9, 2015 | accessdate = February 9, 2015}}</ref><ref>[https://www.bbc.com/news/technology-31296188 Not in front of the telly: Warning over 'listening' TV] BBC News, 2015</ref>
Hackers have misused Smart TV's abilities such as operating source codes for applications and its unsecured connection to the Internet. Passwords, IP address data, and credit card information can be accessed by hackers and even companies for advertisement. A company caught in the act is [[Vizio]].{{cn|date=January 2018}} The confidential documents, codenamed [[Vault 7]] and dated from 2013â2016, include details on [[CIA]]'s software capabilities, such as the ability to compromise smart TVs.<ref>{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/03/07/world/europe/wikileaks-cia-hacking.html |title=WikiLeaks Releases Trove of Alleged C.I.A. Hacking Documents |last=Shane |first=Scott |date=7 March 2017 |access-date=7 March 2017 |last2=Mazzetti |first2=Mark |last3=Rosenberg |first3=Matthew |newspaper=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
===Restriction of access=== Internet websites can block smart TV access to content at will, or tailor the content that will be received by each platform.<ref name="nytBlock">{{Cite news | url = http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2010/10/21/big-networks-block-web-shows-from-google-tv/| title = Big Networks Block Web Shows From Google TV| date = October 21, 2010|work=New York Times| accessdate =December 4, 2010}}</ref> [[Google TV]]-enabled devices were blocked by [[NBC]], [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]], [[CBS]], and [[Hulu]] from accessing their Web content since the launch of Google TV in October 2010. Google TV devices were also blocked from accessing any programs offered by [[Viacom]]âs subsidiaries.<ref name="cnetBlock">{{cite web| url = http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-20023547-1.html| title = Comedy Central, MTV now blocking Google TV| publisher = CNET.com| date = November 22, 2010| accessdate =December 4, 2010}}</ref>
===Reliability=== High-end [[Samsung]] Smart TVs stopped working for at least seven days after a software update.<ref>{{Cite news | url= https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/aug/24/samsung-tv-buyers-furious-after-software-update-leaves-sets-unusable | title = Samsung TV owners furious after software update leaves sets unusable | work= The Guardian | location = London | date = August 24, 2017 | accessdate = August 24, 2017}}</ref> Application providers are rarely upgrading Smart TV apps to the latest version; for example, Netflix does not support older TV versions with new Netflix upgrades.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://devices.netflix.com/en/recommendedtv/2017/|title=Netflix Recommended TVs {{!}} Built for a better Netflix experience|website=devices.netflix.com|language=en|access-date=September 24, 2017}}</ref>

{{POV-check|talk=Neutral point of view check|date=December 2016}}
[[Image:Merryweather.jpg|thumb|The Tempest Prognosticator]] [[File:Tempest Prognosticator.jpg|thumb|Tempest Prognosticator]] The '''tempest prognosticator''', also known as the '''leech barometer''', is a 19th-century invention by [[George Merryweather]] in which [[leech]]es are used in a [[barometer]]. The twelve leeches are kept in small bottles inside the device; when they become agitated by an approaching storm they attempt to climb out of the bottles and trigger a small hammer which strikes a bell. The likelihood of a storm is indicated by the number of times the bell is struck.
==Invention and development== Dr. Merryweather, honorary [[curator]] of the Whitby Literary and Philosophical Society's Museum, detailed the sensitivity that medicinal leeches displayed in reaction to electrical conditions in the atmosphere. He was inspired by two lines from [[Edward Jenner]]'s poem ''Signs of Rain'': "The leech disturbed is newly risen; Quite to the summit of his prison."<ref name="WDispatch">The Weekly Dispatch. 22 March 1851. "[http://www.magma.ca/~jdreid/leech.htm London: The Great Exhibition] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20011224020409/http://www.magma.ca/~jdreid/leech.htm |date=24 December 2001 }}". Accessed 22 January 2007.</ref> Merryweather spent much of 1850 developing his ideas and came up with six designs for what he originally referred to as "An Atmospheric Electromagnetic Telegraph, conducted by Animal Instinct." These ranged from a cheap version, which he envisaged would be used by the government and the shipping industries, to a more expensive design. The expensive design, which took inspiration from the architecture of Indian temples, was made by local craftsmen and shown in the 1851 [[The Great Exhibition|Great Exhibition]] at [[The Crystal Palace]] in [[London]].<ref name="VicWeb">Packer, Martin. The [[Victorian Web]]. "[http://www.scholars.nus.edu.sg/landow/victorian/technology/packer/merryweather.html Dr. George Merryweatherâs 1851 Tempest Prognosticator] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080517045232/http://www.scholars.nus.edu.sg/landow/victorian/technology/packer/merryweather.html |date=17 May 2008 }}." Accessed 22 January 2007.</ref>
On 27 February 1851 he gave a nearly three-hour essay to members of the Philosophical Society entitled "Essay explanatory of the Tempest Prognosticator in the building of the Great Exhibition for the Works of Industry of All Nations."<ref name="VicWeb" />
==Method== The tempest prognosticator comprises twelve pint bottles in a circle around and beneath a large bell. Atop the glasses are small metal tubes which contain a piece of [[whalebone]] and a wire connecting them to small hammers positioned to strike the bell. In his essay Merryweather described the workings of the device: {{cquote|After having arranged this mouse trap contrivance, into each bottle was poured rain water, to the height of an inch and a half; and a leech placed in every bottle, which was to be its future residence; and when influenced by the electromagnetic state of the atmosphere a number of leeches ascended into the tubes; in doing which they dislodged the whalebone and caused the bell to ring.|||George Merryweather|<ref name="VicWeb" />}}
The leech would have difficulty entering the metal tubes but would endeavour to do so if sufficiently motivated by the likelihood of bad weather.<ref name="WDispatch" /> By ringing the bell it would signify that that individual leech is indicating that a storm is approaching. Merryweather referred to the leeches as his "jury of philosophical councilors"<ref name="WDispatch" /> and that the more of them that rang the bell the more likely that a storm would occur.
In his essay Merryweather also noted other features of the design, including the fact that the leeches were placed in glass bottles placed in a circle to prevent them from feeling "the affliction of solitary confinement".<ref name="WDispatch" /><ref name="VicWeb" />
==Accuracy and success== Merryweather spent all of 1850 testing the device, sending a letter to the president of the Philosophical Society and the Whitby Institute, Henry Belcher, to warn him of an impending storm.<ref name="WDispatch" /><ref name="VicWeb" /> The results of 28 of these predictions are kept in the library of [[Whitby Museum]].<ref name="WhitbyMuseum">Whitby Literary & Philosophical Society. 9 July 2006. "[http://www.whitbymuseum.org.uk/d12/misc/index.htm Miscellaneous Exhibits] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070309175537/http://www.whitbymuseum.org.uk/d12/misc/index.htm |date=9 March 2007 }}" at Whitby Museum. Accessed 22 January 2007.</ref> Merryweather stated in his essay the great success that he had had with the device.
Merryweather lobbied for the government to make use of his design around the British coastline but they instead opted for [[Robert FitzRoy]]'s [[storm glass]].<ref name="VicWeb" />
==Replicas== The original device has been lost, but at least three replicas have been made. The hundredth anniversary of the invention brought renewed interest as a replica was made for the 1951 [[Festival of Britain]]. This non-working version was made from the description in a printed copy of Merryweather's essay and a [[intaglio printing|copperplate]] drawing of the original. The device was shown in the [[Dome of Discovery]] and given to the Whitby Philosophical Society when the festival ended. Plans and photographs of this replica were then used to create faithful working models, one at [[Barometer World]] near [[Okehampton]], Devon, and another at the Great Dickens Christmas Fair in [[San Francisco]].<ref name="VicWeb" />

[[File:Traceroll.JPG|250px|thumb|A roll of yellow tracing paper.]] [[File:TRANSLUCENT SHEET.jpg|250px|thumb|Simulation of tracing paper transparency levels]] [[File:Samples of TAKEYO tracing paper.jpg|250px|thumb|Samples of tracing paper]] [[File:GatewayTracingNewRoll.jpg|250px|thumb|Tracing paper roll]] '''Tracing paper''' is paper made to have low [[Opacity (optics)|opacity]], allowing light to pass through. It was originally developed for architects and design engineers to create drawings which could be copied precisely using the [[diazo copy]] process;{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}} it then found many other uses. The original use for drawing and tracing was largely superseded by technologies which do not require diazo copying or manual copying (by tracing) of drawings. The transparency of the paper is achieved by careful selection of the raw materials and the process used to create transparency. [[Cellulose fiber|Cellulose fibre]] forms the basis of the paper, usually from wood species but also from cotton fibre. Often, paper contains other filler materials to enhance opacity and print quality. For tracing or translucent paper, it is necessary to remove any material which obstructs the transmission of light.[http://www.paperonweb.com/A1020.htm How is paper made translucent (grease proof, tracing paper)?] PaperOnWeb == Description == Tracing paper is paper made to have low [[Opacity (optics)|opacity]], allowing light to pass through. It is named as such for its ability for an [[image]] to be [[Copying|traced]] onto it. It was originally developed for architects and design engineers to create drawings which could be copied precisely using the [[diazo copy]] process;{{Citation needed|date=August 2013}} When tracing paper is placed onto a [[picture]], the picture is easily visible through the paper. Thus, it becomes easy to find edges in the picture and trace the image onto the tracing paper. Pure [[cellulose]] [[fiber]] is [[translucent]], and it is the [[air]] trapped between fibers that makes paper [[Opacity (optics)|opaque]] and look white. If the fibers are refined and beaten until all the air is taken out, then the resulting [[Paper|sheet]] will be translucent. Translucent papers are [[Density|dense]] and contain up to 10% [[moisture]] at 50% [[humidity]]. == Production == Tracing paper is usually made from [[Sulfite process|sulfite]] [[Pulp (paper)|pulp]] by reducing the [[fibre]]s to a state of fine [[subdivision (paper)|subdivision]] and [[Hydrolysis|hydrolysing]] them by very prolonged beating in water. There are three main processes to manufacture this type of paper, as follows:- # Through mechanical ârefiningâ of the cellulose fibre to create a fibre which is highly fibrillated and gelatinous, so that in forming the sheet of paper, virtually all air is excluded from the internal structure of the paper. This method produces a very translucent and even looking paper over a range of grammages from 42 to over 280 gsm. # By making a ânormalâ sheet of paper and then filling the spaces between the fibres with a material that has the same refractive index as the cellulose. This was a common process adopted in the USA. The product was frequently called Vellum, although this terminology can refer to a wider range of special papers. Due to the relatively high cost, this method of manufacture has largely disappeared. # As with 2, by making a normal sheet of paper, which is followed by immersing uncut and unloaded paper of good [[Quality (business)|quality]] in [[sulfuric acid]] for a few [[second]]s. The [[acid]] converts some of the [[cellulose]] into [[amyloid]] form having a [[gelatinous]] and impermeable character. When the treated paper is thoroughly washed and dried, the resultant [[Product (business)|product]] is much [[Tensile strength|stronger]] than the original paper. Tracing paper is resistant to [[oil]], [[grease (lubricant)|grease]] and to a large extent impervious to [[water]] and [[gas]]. The [[sizing]] in production will determine whether it is for [[laser printer]] or [[inkjet]]/[[offset printing]]. Tracing paper may be uncoated or coated.{{explain|reason=With what is it coated?|date=December 2017}} Natural tracing paper for laser printing is usually uncoated. The [[Harmonized System|HS]] code for tracing paper is 4806.30.{{cite web|url=http://www.wcoomd.org/en/topics/nomenclature/instrument-and-tools/hs_nomenclature_older_edition/~/media/18FE685D7E8E429996FC0F92A5DDB1C2.ashx|title=Paper and paperboard; articles of paper pulp, of paper or of paperboard|website=wcoomd.org}} Tracing paper can be recycled and also can be made from up to 30% recycled fibre.{{cite web |url= https://www.arjowiggins-tracingpapers.com/faqs |title= Frequently Asked Questions {{!}} Arjoqiggins Creative Papers |work= arjowiggins-tracingpapers.com}} == Technical specifications == * Specifications of natural tracing paper: ** Smooth surface ** Non-[[ageing]] ** [[Acid-free paper|Acid-free]] ** [[Recyclable]] The follows are common [[Standardization|standards]] for tracing paper{{Citation needed|date=May 2010}} Though, generally it is manufactured in grammages over 60 GSM: {| class="wikitable" |- ! {{citation style|date=December 2014}} __NOTOC__ '''User innovation''' refers to [[innovation]] by intermediate users (e.g. user [[firm]]s) or [[consumer]] users (individual [[end-user]]s or user [[communities]]), rather than by suppliers (producers or [[manufacturers]]).<ref>Bogers, M.; Afuah, A.; Bastian, B. (2010), "[http://www.marcelbogers.com/Pubs/Bogers-Afuah-Bastian_2010_JOM_Users-as-innovators.pdf Users as innovators: A review, critique, and future research directions]", Journal of Management, 36 (4): 857â875.</ref> This is a concept closely aligned to [[co-design]], and has been proven to result in more innovative solutions than traditional consultation methodologies.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Mitchell|first1=Val|last2=Ross|first2=Tracy|last3=Sims|first3=Ruth|last4=Parker|first4=Christopher J.|title=Empirical investigation of the impact of using co-design methods when generating proposals for sustainable travel solutions|journal=CoDesign||date=2015|volume=12|issue=4|pages=205-220|doi=10.1080/15710882.2015.1091894|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/full/10.1080/15710882.2015.1091894}}</ref>
[[Eric von Hippel]]<ref>von Hippel, E. (1986). Lead Users: A Source of Novel Product Concepts. Management Science, 32(7), 791-805. {{doi|10.1287/mnsc.32.7.791}}</ref> and others observed that many products and services are actually developed or at least refined, by users, at the site of implementation and use. These ideas are then moved back into the supply network. This is because products are developed to meet the widest possible need; when individual users face problems that the majority of consumers do not, they have no choice but to develop their own modifications to existing products, or entirely new products, to solve their issues. Often, user innovators will share their ideas with manufacturers in hopes of having them produce the product, a process called free revealing.
Based on research on the evolution of Internet technologies and open source software [[Ilkka Tuomi]] {{Harv|Tuomi|2002}} further highlighted the point that users are fundamentally social. User innovation, therefore, is also socially and socio-technically distributed innovation. According to Tuomi,<ref>Tuomi, I: ''Networks of Innovation'', chapter 2. Oxford University Press, 2002.</ref> key uses are often unintended uses invented by user communities that reinterpret and reinvent the meaning of emerging technological opportunities.
The existence of user innovation, for example, by users of industrial robots, rather than the manufacturers of robots {{Harv|Fleck|1988}} is a core part of the argument against the Linear Innovation Model {{Harv|Williams|1996}} i.e. innovation comes from research and development, is then marketed and 'diffuses' to end-users. Instead innovation is a non-linear process involving innovations at all stages.
In 1986 Eric von Hippel introduced the [[lead user]] method that can be used to systematically learn about user innovation in order to apply it in [[new product development]]. In 2007 another specific type of user innovator, the [[creative consumer]] was introduced. These are consumers who adapt, modify, or transform a proprietary offering as opposed to creating completely new products.<ref>Berthon, PR.; Pitt, LF.; McCarthy I. and Kates, SB. (2007) "[http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=959581 When customers get clever: Managerial approaches to dealing with creative consumers]", Business Horizons 50 (1), 39-47</ref>
User innovation has a number of degrees: innovation of use, innovation in services, innovation in configuration of technologies, and finally the innovation of novel technologies themselves. While most user innovation is concentrated in use and configuration of existing products and technologies, and is a normal part of long term innovation, new technologies that are easier for end-users to change and innovate with, and new channels of communication are making it much easier for user innovation to occur and have an impact.
Recent research has focused on Web-based forums that facilitate user (or customer) innovation - referred to as [[virtual customer environment]], these forums help companies partner with their customers in various phases of product development as well as in other value creation activities. For example, [[Threadless]], a T-shirt manufacturing company, relies on the contribution of online community members in the design process. The community includes a group of volunteer designers who submit designs and vote on the designs of others. In addition to free exposure, designers are provided monetary incentives including a $2,500 base award as well as a percentage of T-shirt sales. These incentives allow Threadless to encourage continual user contribution.<ref>Magee,Joe. "[https://hbr.org/2008/10/the-contribution-revolution-letting-volunteers-build-your-business The Contribution Revolution: Letting Volunteers Build Your Business]", [[Harvard Business Review]], October 2008.</ref>

== History == ZOTAC was established in 2006 under the [[umbrella company]] of PC Partner. Its name was derived from the words "zone" and "tact". A year later, ZOTAC created its first ever video card, the ZOTAC [[GeForce 7 series|GeForce 7300 GT]]. In 2008, ZOTAC became the first hardware company to ship video cards with a factory [[Overclocking|overclock]].<ref name=":0" /> It also created the first Mini PC, the MAG ND01.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zotac.com/news/original-mini-pc-brief-history|title=The Original Mini PC (a brief history) {{!}} ZOTAC|date=2015-09-10|language=en|access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref> The MAG ND01 officially debuted in 2009. It featured 2GB of [[DDR2 SDRAM|DDR2]] memory, an [[Intel Atom]] 230 or 330 depending on the model, and a 160GB [[Hard disk drive|HDD]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://hexus.net/tech/news/systems/20585-zotac-dives-nettop-market-mag-mini-pc/|title=ZOTAC dives into nettop market with MAG mini PC - Systems - News - HEXUS.net|last=Parm|first=Mann|date=6 October 2009|website=hexus.net|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-29}}</ref>
In 2015, ZOTAC created a [[Steam Machine (hardware platform)|Steam Machine]] called the NEN.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/zotac-dives-head-first-into-the-steam-machine-battle-with-a-pint-sized-gaming-rig/|title=ZOTAC DIVES HEAD FIRST INTO THE STEAM MACHINE BATTLE WITH A PINT-SIZED GAMING RIG|last=Brad|first=Bourque|date=November 2, 2015|work=|access-date=2016-07-08|via=Digital Trends}}</ref> It featured a [[GeForce 900 series|Nvidia GeForce 960]] and a [[List of Intel Core i5 microprocessors|Intel Core i5-6400T]] Processor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zotac.com/us/product/mini_pcs/nen-steam-machine|title=NEN Steam Machine {{!}} ZOTAC|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-08}}</ref>
In 2016, The MAGNUS EN980 debuted at [[Computex Taipei]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnet.com/products/zotac-magnus-en980/|title=Zotac's water-cooled mini PC is ready for VR and surprisingly affordable|last=Low|first=Aloysius|date=May 31, 2016|work=|access-date=2016-07-10|via=CNET}}</ref> It was the first ever Mini PC that was considered "VR ready" by [[Nvidia]],<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.geek.com/chips/zotac-crammed-a-discrete-gpu-and-water-cooling-into-their-new-mini-pc-1651859/|title=Zotac crammed a discrete GPU and water cooling into their new mini PC|last=Matthews|first=Lee|date=April 8, 2016|work=|access-date=2016-07-12|via=GEEK.com}}</ref> and it featured a Nvidia GTX 980 and an i5 Processor.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.zotac.com/us/product/mini_pcs/magnus-en980-plus-1|title=MAGNUS EN980 Plus {{!}} ZOTAC|last=|first=|date=|website=ZOTAC International|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pcworld.com/article/3045292/hardware/hands-on-with-zotacs-tiny-vr-ready-pc.html|title=Hands-on with Zotac's tiny VR-ready PC|last=Mah|first=Gordon|date=Mar 16, 2016|work=|access-date=2016-07-10|via=PCWorld}}</ref> Also launched is the smallest Mini PC line-up, P Series, and ZOTAC VR GO.
In 2017, Zotac released their GTX 1000 series line including their 1080, 1070, 1060, and also their mini series including the GeForce GTX 1080 Ti Mini. They also introduced their new brand now known as 'Zotac Gaming'. The first product launched under it was the MEK Gaming PC, which was a Mini ITX desktop. In addition to the MEK Gaming PC and graphic cards, Zotac also released a external enclosure that supported Thunderbolt 3 and could host a graphic card up to nine inches long. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.digitaltrends.com/computing/zotac-computex-gtx-1080-ti-mini-more/|title=Zotac Has A Huge Lineup Of Products Heading To Computex Including A GeForce GTX 1080 Ti Mini Card {{!}} Digital Trends|date=2017-05-25|work=Digital Trends|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en-US}}</ref>
In 2018, Zotac has announced their 2000 graphic card series including the GeForce RTX 2080 Ti, GeForce RTX 2080 series, and the GeForce RTX 2070 Series. In addition to graphic cards, Zotac has also released their new line of ZBOX mini PCs in Q2 2018. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zotac.com/news/rtx-20-series-vs-gtx-10-series|title=RTX 20-Series Vs. GTX 10-Series {{!}} ZOTAC|date=2018-09-13|work=ZOTAC|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}</ref>

Extreme series are modified versions of [[NVIDIA]]'s stock graphics cards that includes a modified cooling system, advertised as quieter.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.zotac.com/page/geforce-gtx-10-series|title=ZOTAC - Mini PCs and GeForce GTX Gaming Graphics Cards {{!}} ZOTAC|work=ZOTAC|access-date=2018-10-29|language=en}}</ref>
